keyTakeAways: Peanut allergies in U.S. children have declined significantly since 2015 due to public health recommendations for early introduction of peanuts.
After 2015, the rate of peanut allergies in children aged 0–3 dropped by over 27%, and by over 40% after 2017 guidelines were expanded.
About 40,000 children avoided peanut allergies since 2015, not 60,000 as previously reported.
The LEAP trial (2015) by Gideon Lack and colleagues showed early peanut exposure reduced allergy risk by over 80% and persisted in about 70% of children into adolescence.
Only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists initially followed the 2017 recommendations due to confusion and uncertainty about implementation.
Current guidance recommends introducing peanuts and other major allergens between 4 and 6 months of age without screening.
Safe early exposure can include small amounts of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters.
Advocacy groups like FARE support early introduction as a proven strategy to reduce food allergy prevalence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that early introduction of peanuts to infants reduces the risk of developing food allergies, new research shows a significant real-world decline in peanut allergies in the U.S. Children aged 0 to 3 saw a 27% to 40% drop in allergy rates after 2015 and 2017 public health guidelines recommended early exposure. The study, led by Dr. David Hill at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and published in Pediatrics, analyzed electronic health records and found that approximately 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015. The original LEAP trial by Gideon Lack showed that early allergen exposure reduced allergy risk by over 80%, with lasting effects into adolescence. Despite initial resistance from medical professionals, adoption of the guidelines has increased, and current recommendations encourage parents to introduce peanuts and other allergens between 4 and 6 months of age via small, safe exposures like peanut butter or yogurt. Advocacy groups like FARE support these practices as a vital step in reducing the prevalence of food allergies nationwide.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
